bioghist.p: Howard Melvin Fast (1914-2003) was a Jewish American novelist and television writer, who wrote also under the pen names E. V. Cunningham and Walter Ericson. He was convicted of contempt of Congress in 1950 for refusing to cooperate with the House Un-American Activities Committee. He served three months in jail and was blacklisted. His most well known book was Spartacus.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes manuscripts, typescripts, correspondence and other materials related to Fast's writing and activism. The collection contains original typescripts, printer's copies, and galley proofs of many of Fast's novels and typescripts of his screenplays. Some drafts are annotated by Fast, while others have copy edits. Materials include: correspondence with publishers and royalty statements, mostly from the early 1990s; letters from Fast to Bette Cohen, 1936 (his future wife); photocopies of correspondence with a variety of notable figures, including Upton Sinclair, Eleanor Roosevelt, Paul Robeson, and Erica Jong relating to his reviews of works by fellow authors and his political activities and reporting (1937-1992); posters and handbills for Fast's 1952 run for Congress; and copies of Fast's FBI files. There are also scrapbooks of clippings of articles by and about Fast, reviews of his work, stories about his activism; book announcements and book jackets; photocopies of articles by Fast, including his articles in the Daily Worker, the New York Observer, and the New Times; photographs of Fast and his family; sketches of costume designs, in ink, marker, and gouache; a small number of miscellaneous personal papers; a draft of a dissertation on Fast by Frank Campenni, with some correspondence between Campenni and Fast; handwritten notes for Frenzy; and printed materials, including copies of the Saturday Evening Post, World Over, the New Masses, the Communist, Soviet Literature Review, and other pamphlets and journals.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
